content.webTitle: Nudibranch by Irenosen Okojie review – weird and wild short stories

fields.headline: Nudibranch by Irenosen Okojie review – weird and wild short stories
fields.bodyText: Microdosing LSD has become fashionable over the last few years, with some users reporting improvements to mood and productivity. Reading Irenosen Okojie’s stories is more like taking an old‑fashioned megadose: familiar reality peels away to reveal a world of bizarre transformations, stutters in time, encounters between gods and humans, and the fragmentation, or even the dissolution, of the self. Okojie’s first novel, Butterfly Fish, begins with an empty bottle of palm wine rolling down a London street, presumably a nod to the 1952 novel by the Nigerian writer Amos Tutuola, The Palm-Wine Drinkard, in which an alcoholic young man makes a journey into the afterlife. That novel, which lies splayed open on a table in one story in Nudibranch, and which blends everyday life in Nigeria with the fantastical and phantasmagorical, is a spiritual ancestor to Okojie’s work. Her fiction includes mundane elements – an Ikea sofa, a tower block, an Asda chiller cabinet – but can, at any moment, be overrun by the surreal or supernatural: the tower block is haunted, the chiller cabinet contains the severed head of a time-travelling monk, and atop the Ikea sofa crouches an animal with “a green head, blank human eyes and a crocodile’s tail”, the embodiment of a woman’s loneliness. You need to pay attention when you embark on one of Okojie’s stories, because things can get very strange very quickly. “Filamo”, one of the wildest and best in the collection, begins: “The last monk told the tongue that holding a naked sheep’s head underwater would undo it all.” The suggestion is of some sort of ritual, which abound in Okojie’s work, but a summary of the story’s events – monks exploit wormholes to travel through time collecting artefacts from various ages, while saints Peter, Augustine and Christopher are deployed to keep an eye on them like some kind of ecclesiastical internal affairs unit – doesn’t convey its powerful and singular effect. This resides less in what actually happens (it took me two readings to begin to work that out) and more in its evocation of the fundamental weirdness of Christian symbolism: St Peter was missing an ear, yet had a small translucent dragon’s wing growing against a rib. St Augustine had lost a finger on his left hand but had two hearts, one pumping blood, the other mercury, so much so his tongue became silvery at particular angles. St Christopher had lost an eye and gained a filmy yellow fish iris, which cried seawater no matter his mood. The other highlights are “Mangata”, which describes an albino architect’s return from London to his hometown in Mozambique to build a series of water fountains, its tense atmosphere building towards a horrific climax, and “Dune Dunelm”, about a rootless chef called Canelo. Here Okojie transforms Rapa Nui (the Polynesian name for Easter Island) into a space somewhere between geographical reality and a manifestation of the psyche, as resonant objects from Canelo’s life – “his brain scans … the red paintbrush he’d used to paint the walls of his first apartment … a photograph of his mother” – begin washing up on the shore. The territory Okojie occupies here abuts that of JG Ballard’s The Terminal Beach, another story in which a man reckons with his past on a deserted Pacific island. One of the pleasures of her stories is their unpredictability: it’s often difficult to say where a sentence will end up, let alone a paragraph or an entire scene. Sometimes, however, the writing is more obscure than I think it intends to be. Image-making is Okojie’s great strength, but its potency can get lost in tangled sentences, or similes that confuse rather than make the thing they are describing more vivid. In “Zinzi from Boketto”, for example, she writes that the misshapenness of a circus performer’s hunchback is accentuated for the troupe’s shows, but what does it add to say that this larger hump looks “as if one-eyed creatures grew inside, reaching for their lost sight”? Near the start of the same story “Zinzi from Boketto”, for example, we encounter the following sentence, one of several in the book I find impossible to understand: Rising up as though ready to break from the carriage of squealing oddities to scour the rooftops for iridescent particles of past nights the woman had left behind, while the carriage was sucked into the vortex, Halmin reduced to a mouth in his top hat and the woman using the reins to drag people from the carriage into sudden embraces. In other stories we find “cavernous caves”, “generic, non-specific advice”; “a small smattering”. The occasional tautology is hardly unforgivable, but these are emblematic of an unfinished quality that mars parts of this collection. Okojie displays a poet’s verve for creating unusual combinations of words, but sometimes they, and these stories, are some distance away from their final and most effective iterations. That is frustrating, because, like the nudibranch molluscs of the title story, her work is also notable for its “extraordinary colours and striking forms”. • Nudibranch is published by Dialogue (RRP £14.99). To order a copy go to guardianbookshop.com. Free UK p&p over £15.
